Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: High-yield Fermentation of Sugars to Levulinic Acid
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project focuses on the development of a high-yield fermentation route for the production of levulinic acid (LA). LA is one of the best-suited C5 building blocks for bio-refinery production due to higher value, broad applications, and likely quick adoption by the chemical industry. During Phase I, this project has designed and experimentally validated the concept of a novel fermentation pathway for the production of LA. The focus of this Phase II work will be to transition from this technical proof-of-concept to the development of a lab-scale fermentation process. The limiting enzymatic steps in the designed pathway will first be optimized to reach levels of activity consistent with the flux/yield required for economical production. Variants of the designed pathway incorporating the original and optimized enzymes will subsequently be cloned into suitable fermentation organism(s). Using computational and experimental metabolic engineering tools, knock-out and knock-down mutations will be performed to further optimize flux/yield in the pathway while optimizing for host cell growth. This work represents the first commercial application of enzyme design to rationally engineer novel metabolic pathway that do not have any natural counterpart, bringing us closer to the dream of designer cell factories.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the advancement of a U.S. green chemistry industry and to allow America to take the lead in the commercial production of a new renewable chemical building block. The lack of a high-yield alternative to costly thermo-chemical processes has been preventing widespread adoption of levulinic acid (LA). Because LA can be converted, chemically or biochemically, to synthetic rubber (through isoprene and butenes), bio-fuels (such as kerosene and HMF), polymers (for instance, nylons) and polymer additives (for changing polymer characteristics), the addressable market is in excess of $20B annually. When considered as the end product, LA trades at a considerable higher price than ethanol, the current product of most commercial bio-refineries, and thus can help diversify their product offering and considerably increase their margins.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, a significant fraction of the chemicals and materials produced industrially are manufactured from oil, to the point that around 2-5% of each barrel of fossil oil extracted is used for chemicals. Over the last 70 years, the petrochemical industry has organized itself very efficiently around a small number of C2, C3 and C4 intermediates easily and cheaply accessible petrorefining. These intermediates   are in turn converted into nearly all the industrial chemicals. To displace oil and usher in the age of sustainable chemicals and materials, one similarly need to be able to produce cost-effectively and renewably key intermediates from biomass in biorefineries. This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project focuses on the development of novel fermentation pathways for the production of industrially valuable C5 organic acids, including levulinic acid (LA). LA is one of the best-suited C5 building blocks for biorefinery production due to its high value, large number of easily accessible derivatives, and likely quick adoption by the chemical industry. To date, no bioprocess for LA or related C5 organic acid exist at scale, and known chemical processes have not reached commercial stage due to high cost and lower yield.

Arzeda, has designed and patented several synthetic metabolic pathways to convert biomass to valuable C5 building blocks, including LA, at high yield. These metabolic pathways have been validated in vitro during Phase I, with novel enzymatic activities discovered and characterized. During Phase II Arzeda constructed new fermentation strains able to produce our C5 building blocks at high titer in fermentation chassis that have been used at industrial scale. The initial prototype strains were further optimized to yield significant titers. With these strains, Arzeda is now producing by fermentation one of our C5 intermediate in quantities high to perform application testing with industrial customers and potential strategic partners. For example, the C5 intermediate obtained by fermentation can be converted chemically to a variety of molecules of industrial interest. Among them is green solvent GVL, which is a replacement to the petrochemically produced GBL while having improved properties (such as lower vapor pressure) and less toxicity. Other chemical derivatives of Arzeda’s C5 building block produced by fermentation can be used as flavors and fragrances, as well as for renewable polyurethanes or acrylates materials and paints. These materials and paints, in addition to being produced renewably from plants instead of fossil oil, will also improve performance compared to what is currently on the market: for example to make bio-based Plexiglas with higher scratch, mar and heat tolerance, or to make Spandex fibers with improved stretch properties.  Arzeda is currently engaging both biorefineries with existing plants in which our fermentation process could be deployed, as well as downstream potential partners interesting in sourcing the chemicals for new materials and product applications. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2017
Modified by: Alexandre Zanghellini
